<a id="class_Vector2"></a>

# Vector2

A 2D vector using floating-point coordinates.

<!-- classref-introduction-group -->

## Description

A 2-element structure that can be used to represent 2D coordinates or any other pair of numeric values.

It uses floating-point coordinates. By default, these floating-point values use 32-bit precision, unlike [float](class_float.md) which is always 64-bit. If double precision is needed, compile the engine with the option ``precision=double``.

See [Vector2i](class_vector2i.md) for its integer counterpart.

\ **Note:** In a boolean context, a Vector2 will evaluate to ``false`` if it's equal to ``Vector2(0, 0)``. Otherwise, a Vector2 will always evaluate to ``true``.

<!-- classref-introduction-group -->

<a id="class_Vector2_constant_AXIS_X"></a>

Enumerated value for the X axis. Returned by [max_axis_index()](class_vector2.md#class_Vector2_method_max_axis_index) and [min_axis_index()](class_vector2.md#class_Vector2_method_min_axis_index).<a id="class_Vector2_constant_AXIS_Y"></a>

## Constants

<a id="class_Vector2_constant_ZERO"></a>

<!-- classref-constant -->

**ZERO** = `Vector2(0, 0)` [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_constant_ZERO)

Zero vector, a vector with all components set to ``0``.

<a id="class_Vector2_constant_ONE"></a>

<!-- classref-constant -->

**ONE** = `Vector2(1, 1)` [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_constant_ONE)

One vector, a vector with all components set to ``1``.

<a id="class_Vector2_constant_INF"></a>

<!-- classref-constant -->

**INF** = `Vector2(inf, inf)` [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_constant_INF)

Infinity vector, a vector with all components set to [@GDScript.INF](class_@gdscript.md#class_@GDScript_constant_INF).

<a id="class_Vector2_constant_LEFT"></a>

<!-- classref-constant -->

**LEFT** = `Vector2(-1, 0)` [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_constant_LEFT)

Left unit vector. Represents the direction of left.

<a id="class_Vector2_constant_RIGHT"></a>

<!-- classref-constant -->

**RIGHT** = `Vector2(1, 0)` [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_constant_RIGHT)

Right unit vector. Represents the direction of right.

<a id="class_Vector2_constant_UP"></a>

<!-- classref-constant -->

**UP** = `Vector2(0, -1)` [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_constant_UP)

Up unit vector. Y is down in 2D, so this vector points -Y.

<a id="class_Vector2_constant_DOWN"></a>

<!-- classref-constant -->

**DOWN** = `Vector2(0, 1)` [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_constant_DOWN)

Down unit vector. Y is down in 2D, so this vector points +Y.

<a id="class_Vector2_property_x"></a>

<!-- classref-property -->

[float](class_float.md) **x** = `0.0` [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_property_x)

The vector's X component. Also accessible by using the index position ``[0]``.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_property_y"></a>

<!-- classref-property -->

[float](class_float.md) **y** = `0.0` [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_property_y)

The vector's Y component. Also accessible by using the index position ``[1]``.

<!-- classref-descriptions-group -->

## Method Descriptions

<a id="class_Vector2_method_abs"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **abs**\ (\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_abs)

Returns a new vector with all components in absolute values (i.e. positive).

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_angle"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[float](class_float.md) **angle**\ (\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_angle)

Returns this vector's angle with respect to the positive X axis, or ``(1, 0)`` vector, in radians.

For example, ``Vector2.RIGHT.angle()`` will return zero, ``Vector2.DOWN.angle()`` will return ``PI / 2`` (a quarter turn, or 90 degrees), and ``Vector2(1, -1).angle()`` will return ``-PI / 4`` (a negative eighth turn, or -45 degrees).

\ [Illustration of the returned angle.](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/redot-engine/redot-docs/master/img/vector2_angle.png)\ 

Equivalent to the result of [@GlobalScope.atan2()](class_@globalscope.md#class_@GlobalScope_method_atan2) when called with the vector's [y](class_vector2.md#class_Vector2_property_y) and [x](class_vector2.md#class_Vector2_property_x) as parameters: ``atan2(y, x)``.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_angle_to"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[float](class_float.md) **angle_to**\ (\ to\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_angle_to)

Returns the signed angle to the given vector, in radians.

\ [Illustration of the returned angle.](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/redot-engine/redot-docs/master/img/vector2_angle_to.png)

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_angle_to_point"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[float](class_float.md) **angle_to_point**\ (\ to\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_angle_to_point)

Returns the angle between the line connecting the two points and the X axis, in radians.

\ ``a.angle_to_point(b)`` is equivalent of doing ``(b - a).angle()``.

\ [Illustration of the returned angle.](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/redot-engine/redot-docs/master/img/vector2_angle_to_point.png)

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_aspect"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[float](class_float.md) **aspect**\ (\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_aspect)

Returns the aspect ratio of this vector, the ratio of [x](class_vector2.md#class_Vector2_property_x) to [y](class_vector2.md#class_Vector2_property_y).

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_bezier_derivative"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **bezier_derivative**\ (\ control_1\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md), control_2\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md), end\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md), t\: [float](class_float.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_bezier_derivative)

Returns the derivative at the given `t` on the [BÃ©zier curve](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/B%C3%A9zier_curve) defined by this vector and the given `control_1`, `control_2`, and `end` points.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_bezier_interpolate"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **bezier_interpolate**\ (\ control_1\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md), control_2\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md), end\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md), t\: [float](class_float.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_bezier_interpolate)

Returns the point at the given `t` on the [BÃ©zier curve](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/B%C3%A9zier_curve) defined by this vector and the given `control_1`, `control_2`, and `end` points.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_bounce"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **bounce**\ (\ n\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_bounce)

Returns the vector "bounced off" from a line defined by the given normal `n` perpendicular to the line.

\ **Note:** [bounce()](class_vector2.md#class_Vector2_method_bounce) performs the operation that most engines and frameworks call ``reflect()``.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_ceil"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **ceil**\ (\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_ceil)

Returns a new vector with all components rounded up (towards positive infinity).

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_clamp"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **clamp**\ (\ min\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md), max\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_clamp)

Returns a new vector with all components clamped between the components of `min` and `max`, by running [@GlobalScope.clamp()](class_@globalscope.md#class_@GlobalScope_method_clamp) on each component.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_clampf"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **clampf**\ (\ min\: [float](class_float.md), max\: [float](class_float.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_clampf)

Returns a new vector with all components clamped between `min` and `max`, by running [@GlobalScope.clamp()](class_@globalscope.md#class_@GlobalScope_method_clamp) on each component.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_cross"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[float](class_float.md) **cross**\ (\ with\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_cross)

Returns the 2D analog of the cross product for this vector and `with`.

This is the signed area of the parallelogram formed by the two vectors. If the second vector is clockwise from the first vector, then the cross product is the positive area. If counter-clockwise, the cross product is the negative area. If the two vectors are parallel this returns zero, making it useful for testing if two vectors are parallel.

\ **Note:** Cross product is not defined in 2D mathematically. This method embeds the 2D vectors in the XY plane of 3D space and uses their cross product's Z component as the analog.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_cubic_interpolate"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **cubic_interpolate**\ (\ b\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md), pre_a\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md), post_b\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md), weight\: [float](class_float.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_cubic_interpolate)

Performs a cubic interpolation between this vector and `b` using `pre_a` and `post_b` as handles, and returns the result at position `weight`. `weight` is on the range of 0.0 to 1.0, representing the amount of interpolation.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_cubic_interpolate_in_time"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **cubic_interpolate_in_time**\ (\ b\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md), pre_a\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md), post_b\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md), weight\: [float](class_float.md), b_t\: [float](class_float.md), pre_a_t\: [float](class_float.md), post_b_t\: [float](class_float.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_cubic_interpolate_in_time)

Performs a cubic interpolation between this vector and `b` using `pre_a` and `post_b` as handles, and returns the result at position `weight`. `weight` is on the range of 0.0 to 1.0, representing the amount of interpolation.

It can perform smoother interpolation than [cubic_interpolate()](class_vector2.md#class_Vector2_method_cubic_interpolate) by the time values.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_direction_to"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **direction_to**\ (\ to\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_direction_to)

Returns the normalized vector pointing from this vector to `to`. This is equivalent to using ``(b - a).normalized()``.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_distance_squared_to"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[float](class_float.md) **distance_squared_to**\ (\ to\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_distance_squared_to)

Returns the squared distance between this vector and `to`.

This method runs faster than [distance_to()](class_vector2.md#class_Vector2_method_distance_to), so prefer it if you need to compare vectors or need the squared distance for some formula.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_distance_to"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[float](class_float.md) **distance_to**\ (\ to\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_distance_to)

Returns the distance between this vector and `to`.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_dot"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[float](class_float.md) **dot**\ (\ with\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_dot)

Returns the dot product of this vector and `with`. This can be used to compare the angle between two vectors. For example, this can be used to determine whether an enemy is facing the player.

The dot product will be ``0`` for a right angle (90 degrees), greater than 0 for angles narrower than 90 degrees and lower than 0 for angles wider than 90 degrees.

When using unit (normalized) vectors, the result will always be between ``-1.0`` (180 degree angle) when the vectors are facing opposite directions, and ``1.0`` (0 degree angle) when the vectors are aligned.

\ **Note:** ``a.dot(b)`` is equivalent to ``b.dot(a)``.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_floor"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **floor**\ (\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_floor)

Returns a new vector with all components rounded down (towards negative infinity).

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_from_angle"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **from_angle**\ (\ angle\: [float](class_float.md)\ ) <span class="static">static</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_from_angle)

Creates a **Vector2** rotated to the given `angle` in radians. This is equivalent to doing ``Vector2(cos(angle), sin(angle))`` or ``Vector2.RIGHT.rotated(angle)``.

```
    print(Vector2.from_angle(0)) # Prints (1.0, 0.0)
    print(Vector2(1, 0).angle()) # Prints 0.0, which is the angle used above.
    print(Vector2.from_angle(PI / 2)) # Prints (0.0, 1.0)
```

\ **Note:** The length of the returned **Vector2** is *approximately* ``1.0``, but is is not guaranteed to be exactly ``1.0`` due to floating-point precision issues. Call [normalized()](class_vector2.md#class_Vector2_method_normalized) on the returned **Vector2** if you require a unit vector.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_is_equal_approx"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[bool](class_bool.md) **is_equal_approx**\ (\ to\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_is_equal_approx)

Returns ``true`` if this vector and `to` are approximately equal, by running [@GlobalScope.is_equal_approx()](class_@globalscope.md#class_@GlobalScope_method_is_equal_approx) on each component.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_is_finite"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[bool](class_bool.md) **is_finite**\ (\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_is_finite)

Returns ``true`` if this vector is finite, by calling [@GlobalScope.is_finite()](class_@globalscope.md#class_@GlobalScope_method_is_finite) on each component.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_is_normalized"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[bool](class_bool.md) **is_normalized**\ (\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_is_normalized)

Returns ``true`` if the vector is normalized, i.e. its length is approximately equal to 1.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_is_zero_approx"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[bool](class_bool.md) **is_zero_approx**\ (\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_is_zero_approx)

Returns ``true`` if this vector's values are approximately zero, by running [@GlobalScope.is_zero_approx()](class_@globalscope.md#class_@GlobalScope_method_is_zero_approx) on each component.

This method is faster than using [is_equal_approx()](class_vector2.md#class_Vector2_method_is_equal_approx) with one value as a zero vector.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_length"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[float](class_float.md) **length**\ (\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_length)

Returns the length (magnitude) of this vector.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_length_squared"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[float](class_float.md) **length_squared**\ (\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_length_squared)

Returns the squared length (squared magnitude) of this vector.

This method runs faster than [length()](class_vector2.md#class_Vector2_method_length), so prefer it if you need to compare vectors or need the squared distance for some formula.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_lerp"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **lerp**\ (\ to\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md), weight\: [float](class_float.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_lerp)

Returns the result of the linear interpolation between this vector and `to` by amount `weight`. `weight` is on the range of ``0.0`` to ``1.0``, representing the amount of interpolation.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_limit_length"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **limit_length**\ (\ length\: [float](class_float.md) = 1.0\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_limit_length)

Returns the vector with a maximum length by limiting its length to `length`. If the vector is non-finite, the result is undefined.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_max"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **max**\ (\ with\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_max)

Returns the component-wise maximum of this and `with`, equivalent to ``Vector2(maxf(x, with.x), maxf(y, with.y))``.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_max_axis_index"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[int](class_int.md) **max_axis_index**\ (\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_max_axis_index)

Returns the axis of the vector's highest value. See ``AXIS_*`` constants. If all components are equal, this method returns [AXIS_X](class_vector2.md#class_Vector2_constant_AXIS_X).

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_maxf"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **maxf**\ (\ with\: [float](class_float.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_maxf)

Returns the component-wise maximum of this and `with`, equivalent to ``Vector2(maxf(x, with), maxf(y, with))``.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_min"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **min**\ (\ with\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_min)

Returns the component-wise minimum of this and `with`, equivalent to ``Vector2(minf(x, with.x), minf(y, with.y))``.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_min_axis_index"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[int](class_int.md) **min_axis_index**\ (\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_min_axis_index)

Returns the axis of the vector's lowest value. See ``AXIS_*`` constants. If all components are equal, this method returns [AXIS_Y](class_vector2.md#class_Vector2_constant_AXIS_Y).

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_minf"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **minf**\ (\ with\: [float](class_float.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_minf)

Returns the component-wise minimum of this and `with`, equivalent to ``Vector2(minf(x, with), minf(y, with))``.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_move_toward"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **move_toward**\ (\ to\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md), delta\: [float](class_float.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_move_toward)

Returns a new vector moved toward `to` by the fixed `delta` amount. Will not go past the final value.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_normalized"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **normalized**\ (\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_normalized)

Returns the result of scaling the vector to unit length. Equivalent to ``v / v.length()``. Returns ``(0, 0)`` if ``v.length() == 0``. See also [is_normalized()](class_vector2.md#class_Vector2_method_is_normalized).

\ **Note:** This function may return incorrect values if the input vector length is near zero.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_orthogonal"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **orthogonal**\ (\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_orthogonal)

Returns a perpendicular vector rotated 90 degrees counter-clockwise compared to the original, with the same length.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_posmod"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **posmod**\ (\ mod\: [float](class_float.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_posmod)

Returns a vector composed of the [@GlobalScope.fposmod()](class_@globalscope.md#class_@GlobalScope_method_fposmod) of this vector's components and `mod`.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_posmodv"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **posmodv**\ (\ modv\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_posmodv)

Returns a vector composed of the [@GlobalScope.fposmod()](class_@globalscope.md#class_@GlobalScope_method_fposmod) of this vector's components and `modv`'s components.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_project"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **project**\ (\ b\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_project)

Returns a new vector resulting from projecting this vector onto the given vector `b`. The resulting new vector is parallel to `b`. See also [slide()](class_vector2.md#class_Vector2_method_slide).

\ **Note:** If the vector `b` is a zero vector, the components of the resulting new vector will be [@GDScript.NAN](class_@gdscript.md#class_@GDScript_constant_NAN).

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_reflect"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **reflect**\ (\ line\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_reflect)

Returns the result of reflecting the vector from a line defined by the given direction vector `line`.

\ **Note:** [reflect()](class_vector2.md#class_Vector2_method_reflect) differs from what other engines and frameworks call ``reflect()``. In other engines, ``reflect()`` takes a normal direction which is a direction perpendicular to the line. In Redot, you specify the direction of the line directly. See also [bounce()](class_vector2.md#class_Vector2_method_bounce) which does what most engines call ``reflect()``.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_rotated"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **rotated**\ (\ angle\: [float](class_float.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_rotated)

Returns the result of rotating this vector by `angle` (in radians). See also [@GlobalScope.deg_to_rad()](class_@globalscope.md#class_@GlobalScope_method_deg_to_rad).

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_round"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **round**\ (\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_round)

Returns a new vector with all components rounded to the nearest integer, with halfway cases rounded away from zero.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_sign"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **sign**\ (\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_sign)

Returns a new vector with each component set to ``1.0`` if it's positive, ``-1.0`` if it's negative, and ``0.0`` if it's zero. The result is identical to calling [@GlobalScope.sign()](class_@globalscope.md#class_@GlobalScope_method_sign) on each component.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_slerp"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **slerp**\ (\ to\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md), weight\: [float](class_float.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_slerp)

Returns the result of spherical linear interpolation between this vector and `to`, by amount `weight`. `weight` is on the range of 0.0 to 1.0, representing the amount of interpolation.

This method also handles interpolating the lengths if the input vectors have different lengths. For the special case of one or both input vectors having zero length, this method behaves like [lerp()](class_vector2.md#class_Vector2_method_lerp).

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_slide"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **slide**\ (\ n\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_slide)

Returns a new vector resulting from sliding this vector along a line with normal `n`. The resulting new vector is perpendicular to `n`, and is equivalent to this vector minus its projection on `n`. See also [project()](class_vector2.md#class_Vector2_method_project).

\ **Note:** The vector `n` must be normalized. See also [normalized()](class_vector2.md#class_Vector2_method_normalized).

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_snapped"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **snapped**\ (\ step\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_snapped)

Returns a new vector with each component snapped to the nearest multiple of the corresponding component in `step`. This can also be used to round the components to an arbitrary number of decimals.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_method_snappedf"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **snappedf**\ (\ step\: [float](class_float.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_method_snappedf)

Returns a new vector with each component snapped to the nearest multiple of `step`. This can also be used to round the components to an arbitrary number of decimals.

<hr class="classref-section-separator">

<!-- classref-descriptions-group -->

## Operator Descriptions

<a id="class_Vector2_operator_neq_Vector2"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[bool](class_bool.md) **operator !=**\ (\ right\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_operator_neq_Vector2)

Returns ``true`` if the vectors are not equal.

\ **Note:** Due to floating-point precision errors, consider using [is_equal_approx()](class_vector2.md#class_Vector2_method_is_equal_approx) instead, which is more reliable.

\ **Note:** Vectors with [@GDScript.NAN](class_@gdscript.md#class_@GDScript_constant_NAN) elements don't behave the same as other vectors. Therefore, the results from this operator may not be accurate if NaNs are included.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_operator_mul_Transform2D"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **operator ***\ (\ right\: [Transform2D](class_transform2d.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_operator_mul_Transform2D)

Inversely transforms (multiplies) the **Vector2** by the given [Transform2D](class_transform2d.md) transformation matrix, under the assumption that the transformation basis is orthonormal (i.e. rotation/reflection is fine, scaling/skew is not).

\ ``vector * transform`` is equivalent to ``transform.inverse() * vector``. See [Transform2D.inverse()](class_transform2d.md#class_Transform2D_method_inverse).

For transforming by inverse of an affine transformation (e.g. with scaling) ``transform.affine_inverse() * vector`` can be used instead. See [Transform2D.affine_inverse()](class_transform2d.md#class_Transform2D_method_affine_inverse).

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_operator_mul_Vector2"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **operator ***\ (\ right\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_operator_mul_Vector2)

Multiplies each component of the **Vector2** by the components of the given **Vector2**.

```
    print(Vector2(10, 20) * Vector2(3, 4)) # Prints (30.0, 80.0)
```

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_operator_mul_float"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **operator ***\ (\ right\: [float](class_float.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_operator_mul_float)

Multiplies each component of the **Vector2** by the given [float](class_float.md).

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_operator_mul_int"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **operator ***\ (\ right\: [int](class_int.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_operator_mul_int)

Multiplies each component of the **Vector2** by the given [int](class_int.md).

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_operator_sum_Vector2"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **operator +**\ (\ right\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_operator_sum_Vector2)

Adds each component of the **Vector2** by the components of the given **Vector2**.

```
    print(Vector2(10, 20) + Vector2(3, 4)) # Prints (13.0, 24.0)
```

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_operator_dif_Vector2"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **operator -**\ (\ right\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_operator_dif_Vector2)

Subtracts each component of the **Vector2** by the components of the given **Vector2**.

```
    print(Vector2(10, 20) - Vector2(3, 4)) # Prints (7.0, 16.0)
```

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_operator_div_Vector2"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **operator /**\ (\ right\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_operator_div_Vector2)

Divides each component of the **Vector2** by the components of the given **Vector2**.

```
    print(Vector2(10, 20) / Vector2(2, 5)) # Prints (5.0, 4.0)
```

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_operator_div_float"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **operator /**\ (\ right\: [float](class_float.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_operator_div_float)

Divides each component of the **Vector2** by the given [float](class_float.md).

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_operator_div_int"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **operator /**\ (\ right\: [int](class_int.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_operator_div_int)

Divides each component of the **Vector2** by the given [int](class_int.md).

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_operator_lt_Vector2"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[bool](class_bool.md) **operator <**\ (\ right\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_operator_lt_Vector2)

Compares two **Vector2** vectors by first checking if the X value of the left vector is less than the X value of the `right` vector. If the X values are exactly equal, then it repeats this check with the Y values of the two vectors. This operator is useful for sorting vectors.

\ **Note:** Vectors with [@GDScript.NAN](class_@gdscript.md#class_@GDScript_constant_NAN) elements don't behave the same as other vectors. Therefore, the results from this operator may not be accurate if NaNs are included.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_operator_lte_Vector2"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[bool](class_bool.md) **operator <=**\ (\ right\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_operator_lte_Vector2)

Compares two **Vector2** vectors by first checking if the X value of the left vector is less than or equal to the X value of the `right` vector. If the X values are exactly equal, then it repeats this check with the Y values of the two vectors. This operator is useful for sorting vectors.

\ **Note:** Vectors with [@GDScript.NAN](class_@gdscript.md#class_@GDScript_constant_NAN) elements don't behave the same as other vectors. Therefore, the results from this operator may not be accurate if NaNs are included.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_operator_eq_Vector2"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[bool](class_bool.md) **operator ==**\ (\ right\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_operator_eq_Vector2)

Returns ``true`` if the vectors are exactly equal.

\ **Note:** Due to floating-point precision errors, consider using [is_equal_approx()](class_vector2.md#class_Vector2_method_is_equal_approx) instead, which is more reliable.

\ **Note:** Vectors with [@GDScript.NAN](class_@gdscript.md#class_@GDScript_constant_NAN) elements don't behave the same as other vectors. Therefore, the results from this operator may not be accurate if NaNs are included.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_operator_gt_Vector2"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[bool](class_bool.md) **operator >**\ (\ right\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_operator_gt_Vector2)

Compares two **Vector2** vectors by first checking if the X value of the left vector is greater than the X value of the `right` vector. If the X values are exactly equal, then it repeats this check with the Y values of the two vectors. This operator is useful for sorting vectors.

\ **Note:** Vectors with [@GDScript.NAN](class_@gdscript.md#class_@GDScript_constant_NAN) elements don't behave the same as other vectors. Therefore, the results from this operator may not be accurate if NaNs are included.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_operator_gte_Vector2"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[bool](class_bool.md) **operator >=**\ (\ right\: [Vector2](class_vector2.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_operator_gte_Vector2)

Compares two **Vector2** vectors by first checking if the X value of the left vector is greater than or equal to the X value of the `right` vector. If the X values are exactly equal, then it repeats this check with the Y values of the two vectors. This operator is useful for sorting vectors.

\ **Note:** Vectors with [@GDScript.NAN](class_@gdscript.md#class_@GDScript_constant_NAN) elements don't behave the same as other vectors. Therefore, the results from this operator may not be accurate if NaNs are included.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_operator_idx_int"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[float](class_float.md) **operator []**\ (\ index\: [int](class_int.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_operator_idx_int)

Access vector components using their `index`. ``v[0]`` is equivalent to ``v.x``, and ``v[1]`` is equivalent to ``v.y``.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_operator_unplus"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **operator unary+**\ (\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_operator_unplus)

Returns the same value as if the ``+`` was not there. Unary ``+`` does nothing, but sometimes it can make your code more readable.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector2_operator_unminus"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector2](class_vector2.md) **operator unary-**\ (\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector2_operator_unminus)

Returns the negative value of the **Vector2**. This is the same as writing ``Vector2(-v.x, -v.y)``. This operation flips the direction of the vector while keeping the same magnitude. With floats, the number zero can be either positive or negative.
